miscs.name: About this Documentation
miscs.desc:
The goal of this documentation is to comprehensively explain the Luvit API, both from a reference as well as a conceptual point of view. Each section describes a built-in module or high-level concept.

Where appropriate, property types, method arguments, and the arguments provided to event handlers are detailed in a list underneath the topic heading.

Every .html document has a corresponding .json document presenting the same information in a structured manner. This feature is experimental, and added for the benefit of IDEs and other utilities that wish to do programmatic things with the documentation.

Every .html and .json file is generated based on the corresponding .markdown file in the doc/api/ folder in luvit's source tree. The documentation is generated using the tools/doc/generate.js program. The HTML template is located at doc/template.html.

There's also a lot of examples in this repo that may be helpful.

miscs.name: Synopsis
miscs.desc:
The luvit CLI tool can be used as a scripting platform just like node. This can be used to run lua scripts as standalone servers, clients, or other tools.

This simple web server written in Luvit responds with Hello World for every request. 

local http = require('http')

http.createServer(function (req, res)
  local body = "Hello world\n"
  res:setHeader("Content-Type", "text/plain")
  res:setHeader("Content-Length", #body)
  res:finish(body)
end):listen(1337, '127.0.0.1')

print('Server running at http://127.0.0.1:1337/')

To run the server, put the code into a file called server.lua and execute it with using luvit 

> luvit server.lua
Server running at http://127.0.0.1:1337/

This script is a standalone HTTP server, there is no need for Apache or Nginx to act as host. All of the examples in the documentation can be run similarly.

modules.name: buffer
modules.desc:
A mutable buffer using ffi for luvit.

buffer = require('buffer')

classes.name: buffer.Buffer
classes.desc: Main buffer class

methods.name: Buffer:inspect
methods.desc: Inspect a buffer. Returns a string of hexes like <Buffer Hexes>

methods.name: Buffer:readUInt8
methods.desc: Reads unsigned 8 bit int at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readInt8
methods.desc: Read 8 bit int at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readUInt16LE
methods.desc: Read a unsigned 16 bit integer in little endian at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readUInt16BE
methods.desc: Read a unsigned 16 bit integer in big endian at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readInt16LE
methods.desc: Read a signed 16 bit integer in little endian at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readInt16BE
methods.desc: Read a signed 16 bit integer in big endian at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readUInt32LE
methods.desc: Read a unsigned 32 bit integer in little endian at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readInt32LE
methods.desc: Read a signed 32 bit integer in little endian at offset

methods.name: Buffer:readInt32BE
methods.desc: Read a signed 32 bit integer in big endian at offset

methods.name: Buffer:toString
methods.desc: Stringify the buffer from the ith to the jth position, or the whole thing if i and j arent specified

modules.name: child_process
modules.desc: It is possible to stream data through a child's stdin, stdout, and stderr in a fully non-blocking way.

methods.name: spawn
methods.desc:
Spawns a command line process.

Since the data coming in is a stream, you may want to pass it through a filter like the luvit line emitter package to get lines instead. 

function example()
  local LineEmitter = require('line-emitter').LineEmitter
  local childProcess = require('childprocess')
  local function run(command, args, options)
    local stdout, stderr = LineEmitter:new(), LineEmitter:new()
    local child = childProcess.spawn(command, args, options)
    child.stdout:pipe(stdout)
    child.stderr:pipe(stderr)
    return child, stdout, stderr
  end

  local child = run('ls', {'-hal'}, {})
  child:on('data', print)
end

example()

total 2
drwxr-xr-x   31 root  wheel   1.1K Aug 21 16:39 .
drwxr-xr-x   31 root  wheel   1.1K Aug 21 16:39 ..

Options can have the following k-v pairs: 

detached = [Boolean]
stdio = [Array]
cwd = [String]
uid = [Number]
gid = [Number]

methods.name: exec
methods.desc:
Executes the supplied command and returns data returned in the callback.
The callback can be either a function or a thread for coroutine style code.
The command can have arguments e.g. childprocess.exec('ls -a', print).

Options can have the following k-v pairs: 

timeout = [Number]  
maxBuffer = [Integer, default: 4 * 1024]
signal = [String, default: 'SIGTERM'] 
shell = [String, default: 'cmd.exe' or '/bin/sh']

Additionally since this function delegates to Spawn, all spawn option k-vs are also valid.

methods.name: execFile
methods.desc: Similiar to exec but the arguments for the command/file must be supplied as a string to the second parameter. Also, callback is optional as well here.

modules.name: codec
modules.desc:
Utilities for working with luvit streams and codecs.

local codec = require('codec')

methods.name: wrapEmitter
methods.desc: Wraps an emitter with coroutines. Returns read and write functions.

methods.name: wrapStream
methods.desc: Given a raw uv_stream_t userdara, return coro-friendly read/write functions.

methods.name: chain
methods.desc: Allows one to chain coroutines

modules.name: core
modules.desc: Core object model for luvit using simple prototypes and inheritance. We support single inheritance for classes.

methods.name: instanceof
methods.desc:
Given an object which inherits from a class, and a class, returns whether the object is an instance of that class. 

> em = core.Emitter:new()
> core.instanceof(em, core.Emitter)
true

classes.name: core.Object
classes.desc: The base object class. It provides simple prototypal inheritance and inheritable constructors. All other objects inherit from this.

methods.name: Object:create
methods.desc: Creates a new instance of the base object

methods.name: Object:new
methods.desc:
Creates a new instance and calls obj:initialize(...) if it exists. 

local Rectangle = Object:extend()
function Rectangle:initialize(w, h)
  self.w = w
  self.h = h
end
function Rectangle:getArea()
  return self.w * self.h
end
local rect = Rectangle:new(3, 4)
p(rect:getArea())

methods.name: Object:extend
methods.desc:
Creates a new sub-class. 

local Square = Rectangle:extend()
function Square:initialize(w)
  self.w = w
  self.h = h
end

classes.name: core.Emitter
classes.desc:
This class can be used directly whenever an event emitter is needed. 

local emitter = Emitter:new()
emitter:on('foo', p)
emitter:emit('foo', 1, 2, 3)

Also it can easily be sub-classed. 

local Custom = Emitter:extend()
local c = Custom:new()
c:on('bar', onBar)

Unlike EventEmitter in node.js, Emitter class doesn't auto binds self reference. This means, if a callback handler is expecting a self reference, utils.bind() should be used, and the callback handler should have a self at the beginning its parameter list. 

function some_func(self, a, b, c) end
emitter:on('end', utils.bind(some_func, emitter))
emitter:emit('end', 'a', 'b', 'c')

methods.name: Emitter:on
methods.desc:
Adds an event listener (callback) for the named event name. 

em = Emitter:new()
em:on('data', function(data) print(data) end)

methods.name: Emitter:once
methods.desc: Same as Emitter:on except it de-registers itself after the first event.

methods.name: Emitter:listenerCount
methods.desc: Returns the count of the listeners bound to an event with the name name

methods.name: Emitter:emit
methods.desc:
Emit a named event to all listeners with optional data arguments 

> em = Emitter:new()
> em:on('data', function(data) print(data) end)
> em:emit('data', 'foo')
'foo'

methods.name: Emitter:removeListener
methods.desc:
Removes a listener so it no longer catches events 

> em = Emitter:new()
> em:on('data', function(data) print(data) end)
> em:emit('data', 'foo')
foo
> em:removeListener('data', function() em:emit('data', 'foo') end)
> -- nothing printed

methods.name: Emitter:removeAllListeners
methods.desc: Removes all listeners. Name is optional and if supplied will make it act like removeListener

methods.name: Emitter:listeners
methods.desc: Returns listeners for the event with name name

methods.name: Emitter:wrap
methods.desc:
Utility that binds the named method self[name] for use as a callback. The first argument (err) is re-routed to the "error" event instead. 

local Joystick = Emitter:extend()
function Joystick:initialize(device)
  self:wrap("onOpen")
  FS.open(device, self.onOpen)
end
function Joystick:onOpen(fd)
  -- and so forth
end

methods.name: Emitter:propagate
methods.desc: Propagate the event to another emitter.

classes.name: core.Error
classes.desc: This is for code that wants structured error messages.

methods.name: Error:initialize
methods.desc: How to handle strings

modules.name: datagram_|_udp
modules.desc:
Node-style udp module for luvit

local dgram = require('dgram')

methods.name: createSocket
methods.desc: Creates a new datagram socket Callback is triggered every time the 'message' event gets emitted

classes.name: dgram.Socket
classes.desc: Socket extends Emitter and inherits all the events thereof. The dgram Socket class encapsulates the datagram functionality. It should be created via dgram.createSocket(...)

methods.name: Socket:recvStart
methods.desc: Start receiving on socket

methods.name: Socket:recvStop
methods.desc: Stop listening on socket

methods.name: Socket:setTimeout
methods.desc: Sets a socket timeout

methods.name: Socket:send
methods.desc: Sends data down the udp socket

methods.name: Socket:bind
methods.desc: Starts listening on the specified port and host.

methods.name: Socket:close
methods.desc: Closes a socket instance and fires the callback after cleanup

methods.name: Socket:address
methods.desc: Returns an object containing the address information for a socket. For UDP sockets, this object will contain address , family and port.

methods.name: Socket:setBroadcast

params.textRaw: status - Boolean Sets or clears the SO_BROADCAST socket option. When this option is set, UDP packets may be sent to a local interface's broadcast address.
params.name: status
params.desc: Boolean Sets or clears the SO_BROADCAST socket option. When this option is set, UDP packets may be sent to a local interface's broadcast address.

methods.desc: Sets membership status for a multicast group. Op can be 'join' or 'leave'.

methods.name: Socket:setMembership
methods.desc: Sets membership status for a multicast group. Op can be 'join' or 'leave'.

methods.name: Socket:addMembership

params.textRaw: multicastInterface String, Optional Tells the kernel to join a multicast group with IP_ADD_MEMBERSHIP socket option.
params.name: multicastInterface
params.desc: String, Optional Tells the kernel to join a multicast group with IP_ADD_MEMBERSHIP socket option.

methods.desc: If multicastInterface is not specified, the OS will try to add membership to all valid interfaces.

methods.name: Socket:dropMembership

params.textRaw: multicastInterface String, Optional Opposite of addMembership - tells the kernel to leave a multicast group with IP_DROP_MEMBERSHIP socket option. This is automatically called by the kernel when the socket is closed or process terminates, so most apps will never need to call this.
params.name: multicastInterface
params.desc: String, Optional Opposite of addMembership - tells the kernel to leave a multicast group with IP_DROP_MEMBERSHIP socket option. This is automatically called by the kernel when the socket is closed or process terminates, so most apps will never need to call this.

methods.desc: If multicastInterface is not specified, the OS will try to drop membership to all valid interfaces.

methods.name: Socket:setTTL

params.textRaw: ttl Integer Sets the IP_TTL socket option. TTL stands for "Time to Live," but in this context it specifies the number of IP hops that a packet is allowed to go through. Each router or gateway that forwards a packet decrements the TTL. If the TTL is decremented to 0 by a router, it will not be forwarded. Changing TTL values is typically done for network probes or when multicasting.
params.name: ttl
params.desc: Integer Sets the IP_TTL socket option. TTL stands for "Time to Live," but in this context it specifies the number of IP hops that a packet is allowed to go through. Each router or gateway that forwards a packet decrements the TTL. If the TTL is decremented to 0 by a router, it will not be forwarded. Changing TTL values is typically done for network probes or when multicasting.

methods.desc: The argument to setTTL() is a number of hops between 1 and 255. The default on most systems is 64.

modules.name: dns
modules.desc:
Node-style dns module for luvit

local dns = require('dns')

methods.name: setTimeout
methods.desc: Sets the timeout to the default timeout of 2 seconds

methods.name: setDefaultTimeout
methods.desc: Sets the timeout to the default timeout of 2 seconds

methods.name: loadResolver
methods.desc:
Options is a table with key file. E,g 

{file = '/etc/resolv.conf'}

modules.name: fs
modules.desc:
Node-style filesystem module for luvit

local fs = require('fs')

Uses lib uv under the hood. A lot of these fuctions are very similiar to linux system calls and can be understood by reading the man pages of linux command line commnds with the same names.

The asynchronous form always takes a completion callback as its last argument. The arguments passed to the completion callback depend on the method, but the first argument is always reserved for an exception. If the operation was completed successfully, then the first argument will be null or undefined.

Sync versions of functions usually return true if they succeed or an error if they dont and no data is expected. Otherwise they return the data on success.

methods.name: close
methods.desc: Close a file. No arguments other than a possible exception are given to the completion callback.

methods.name: closeSync
methods.desc: Synchronous file close

methods.name: open
methods.desc:
Asynchronous file open. flags can be:

  • 'r' - Open file for reading. An exception occurs if the file does not exist.

  • 'r+' - Open file for reading and writing. An exception occurs if the file does not exist.

  • 'rs' - Open file for reading in synchronous mode. Instructs the operating system to bypass the local file system cache.

    This is primarily useful for opening files on NFS mounts as it allows you to skip the potentially stale local cache. It has a very real impact on I/O performance so don't use this flag unless you need it.

    Note that this doesn't turn fs.open() into a synchronous blocking call. If that's what you want then you should be using fs.openSync()

  • 'rs+' - Open file for reading and writing, telling the OS to open it synchronously. See notes for 'rs' about using this with caution.

  • 'w' - Open file for writing. The file is created (if it does not exist) or truncated (if it exists).

  • 'wx' - Like 'w' but fails if path exists.

  • 'w+' - Open file for reading and writing. The file is created (if it does not exist) or truncated (if it exists).

  • 'wx+' - Like 'w+' but fails if path exists.

  • 'a' - Open file for appending. The file is created if it does not exist.

  • 'ax' - Like 'a' but fails if path exists.

  • 'a+' - Open file for reading and appending. The file is created if it does not exist.

  • 'ax+' - Like 'a+' but fails if path exists.

mode sets the file mode (permission and sticky bits), but only if the file was created. It defaults to 0666, readable and writeable.

The callback gets two arguments (err, fd).

The exclusive flag 'x' (O_EXCL flag in open(2)) ensures that path is newly created. On POSIX systems, path is considered to exist even if it is a symlink to a non-existent file. The exclusive flag may or may not work with network file systems.

On Linux, positional writes don't work when the file is opened in append mode. The kernel ignores the position argument and always appends the data to the end of the file.

methods.name: openSync
methods.desc: Synchronous version of fs.open(). Returns an integer representing the file descriptor.

methods.name: read
methods.desc:
Read data from the file specified by fd.

offset is the offset in the buffer to start reading at.

size is an integer specifying the number of bytes to read. Defaults to 4096.

The callback is given the three arguments, (err, bytesRead, buffer).

methods.name: readSync
methods.desc: Synchronous file read

methods.name: unlink
methods.desc: Asynchronous delete file. No arguments other than a possible exception are given to the completion callback.

methods.name: unlinkSync
methods.desc: Synchronous unlink. Returns undefined.

methods.name: write
methods.desc: Writes a data in string data to a file fd calling a function callback with err or nil when done. offset is the offset in the buffer to start writing at.

methods.name: writeSync
methods.desc: Synchronous version of the above write function

methods.name: mkdir
methods.desc: Creates a directory with name path and returns a callback with err or nil. Mode is the permissions set on the directory, defaults to octal 0777

methods.name: mkdirSync
methods.desc: Sync version of mkdir.

methods.name: mkdtemp
methods.desc: Makes a directory from a template object

methods.name: mkdtempSync
methods.desc: Sync version of mkdtemp

methods.name: rmdir
methods.desc: Removes a directory

methods.name: rmdirSync
methods.desc: Sync version of rmdir

methods.name: readdir
methods.desc: Reads a directory, returning files and folders in it in the callback. First arg of cb is nil or err This function is not recursive. Use the luvit-walk package for a recursive variant

methods.name: readdirSync
methods.desc: Sync version of readdir

methods.name: scandir
methods.desc: Similiar to readdir but the callback here gets a function instead of a table containing the list of files. Every time this function is invoked it returns the name of the file/dir and the type of the file/dir (either file or directory).

methods.name: scandirSync
methods.desc: Simply returns the iterator function retrieved in the async scandirs callback

methods.name: exists
methods.desc: Checks if a file exists. Callback is called with true or false and an error or nil in the first and second args respectively.

methods.name: existsSync
methods.desc: Sync version of exists. Returns the args the callback gets in the async version

methods.name: stat
methods.desc:
> fs.stat('/', function(err, stat) print(err) statData = stat end)
uv_fs_t: 0x00ada5c0
> nil
statData
{ mtime = { nsec = 0, sec = 1440200375 },
  atime = { nsec = 0, sec = 1444233226 }, ino = 2, nlink = 31, uid = 0,
  blksize = 4096, ctime = { nsec = 0, sec = 1440200375 }, rdev = 0,
  size = 1122, mode = 16877, type = 'directory',
  birthtime = { nsec = 0, sec = 1428616447 }, flags = 0, gid = 0, gen = 0,
  dev = 16777220, blocks = 0 }

methods.name: statSync
methods.desc: Sync version of fs.stat. Returns either an error or the stat object

methods.name: fstat
methods.desc: Similiar to stat but expects a file descriptor as retrieved from open or read instead of a path

methods.name: fstatSync
methods.desc: Sync fstat

methods.name: lstat
methods.desc: lstat() is identical to stat(), except that if path is a symbolic link, then the link itself is stat-ed, not the file that it refers to.

methods.name: lstatSync
methods.desc: Sync lstat

methods.name: rename
methods.desc: Renames a file or directory located at the given path to the new path. The callback is called with either the error or true

methods.name: renameSync
methods.desc: Sync version of rename

methods.name: fsync
methods.desc:
Async fsync. No arguments other than a possible exception are given to the completion callback.

fsync() transfers ("flushes") all modified in-core data of (i.e., modified buffer cache pages for) the file referred to by the file descriptor fd to the disk device (or other permanent storage device) so that all changed information can be retrieved even after the system crashed or was rebooted. This includes writing through or flushing a disk cache if present. The call blocks until the device reports that the transfer has completed. It also flushes metadata information associated with the file (see stat(2)).

Calling fsync() does not necessarily ensure that the entry in the directory containing the file has also reached disk. For that an explicit fsync() on a file descriptor for the directory is also needed.

methods.name: fsyncSync
methods.desc: Sync version of fsync

methods.name: fdatasync
methods.desc:
fdatasync() is similar to fsync(), but does not flush modified metadata unless that metadata is needed in order to allow a subsequent data retrieval to be correctly handled. For example, changes to st_atime or st_mtime (respectively, time of last access and time of last modification; see stat(2)) do not require flushing because they are not necessary for a subsequent data read to be handled correctly. On the other hand, a change to the file size (st_size, as made by say ftruncate(2)), would require a metadata flush.

The aim of fdatasync() is to reduce disk activity for applications that do not require all metadata to be synchronized with the disk.

methods.name: fdatasyncSync
methods.desc: Sync fdatasync

methods.name: ftruncate
methods.desc:
Shrink or extend the size of each FILE to the specified size

A FILE argument that does not exist is created.

If a FILE is larger than the specified size, the extra data is lost. If a FILE is shorter, it is extended and the extended part (hole) reads as zero bytes.

methods.name: ftruncateSync
methods.desc: Sync truncate

methods.name: sendFile
methods.desc: sendfile() copies data between one file descriptor and another. Because this copying is done within the kernel, sendfile() is more efficient than the combination of read(2) and write(2), which would require transferring data to and from user space.

methods.name: sendfileSync
methods.desc: Sync sendfile

methods.name: access
methods.desc:
Tests a user's permissions for the file specified by path. mode is an optional integer that specifies the accessibility checks to be performed. The following constants define the possible values of mode. It is possible to create a mask consisting of the bitwise OR of two or more values.

  • fs.F_OK - File is visible to the calling process. This is useful for determining if a file exists, but says nothing about rwx permissions. Default if no mode is specified.
  • fs.R_OK - File can be read by the calling process.
  • fs.W_OK - File can be written by the calling process.
  • fs.X_OK - File can be executed by the calling process. This has no effect on Windows (will behave like fs.F_OK).
  • The final argument, callback, is a callback function that is invoked with a possible error argument. If any of the accessibility checks fail, the error argument will be populated. The following example checks if the file /etc/passwd can be read and written by the current process.

methods.name: chmod
methods.desc: Asynchronous fchmod(2). No arguments other than a possible exception are given to the completion callback.

methods.name: chmodSync
methods.desc: Sync chmod.

methods.name: fchmod
methods.desc: Asynchronous fchmod(2). No arguments other than a possible exception are given to the completion callback.

methods.name: utime
methods.desc: Async utime. Chages file last access and modification times

methods.name: utimeSync
methods.desc: Sync utime

methods.name: futime
methods.desc: Changes file timestamps

methods.name: futimeSync
methods.desc: Sync futime

methods.name: link
methods.desc:
link() creates a new link (also known as a hard link) to an existing file. If newpath exists it will not be overwritten.

This new name may be used exactly as the old one for any operation; both names refer to the same file (and so have the same permissions and ownership) and it is impossible to tell which name was the "original".

methods.name: linkSync
methods.desc: Sync link

methods.name: symlink
methods.desc: Creates soft link instead of a hard link as in link

methods.name: symlinkSync
methods.desc: Sync symlink

methods.name: readlink
methods.desc: Asynchronous readlink(2). The callback gets two arguments (err, linkString). Prints value of a symbolic link or canonical file name

methods.name: readlinkSync
methods.desc: Sync readlink

methods.name: chown
methods.desc: Async chown. Changes ownership of a file

methods.name: chownSync
methods.desc: Sync chown

methods.name: fchown
methods.desc: Like chown but works with file descriptors

methods.name: fchownSync
methods.desc: Sync fchown

methods.name: readFile
methods.desc: Reads a file to a string buffer which is returned as the second argument in the callback. Works with virtual filesystems as well

methods.name: readFileSync
methods.desc: Sync readFile

methods.name: writeFile
methods.desc: Writes a file.

methods.name: writeFileSync
methods.desc: Sync writeFile

methods.name: appendFile
methods.desc: Appends data to a file

methods.name: appendFileSync
methods.desc: Sync version of append file.

methods.name: createWriteStream
methods.desc: Creates and returns a new write stream, that is an instance of the aforementioned WriteStream class with the given path and options

methods.name: createReadStream
methods.desc: Function which creates and returns a new read stream instance with the set options and path

modules.name: fs.fchmodsync(fd,_mode0
modules.desc: Sync fchmod

classes.name: fs.WriteStream
classes.desc:
Creates a writeable stream You can extend the following class methods in your extended instance.

e.g. 

local path, cb, chunk = 'valid/path', validFunc, 'validString'
local WritableChild = fs.WriteStream:extend()
function WritableChild:_write(data, callback)
  print('Wrote: '..data)
  callback()
end
local writable = WritableChild:new(path, cb)
writable:on('open', function() print('file opened')
writable:write(chunk) -- optional callback
writable:close()

methods.name: WriteStream:initialize
methods.desc:
You can set the path to the file and options here. Options is a table with the following key-value pairs

  • fd - File descriptor

  • flags - 'w' for write. See fs.open for other possible flags

  • mode - file mode to write to. Defaults to 438 which is equivalent to octal 0666

  • start - Start position

methods.name: WriteStream:open
methods.desc: Callback to fire when the write stream is opened. This callback gets no arguments. An open event is also emitted with the file descriptor when the file is opened

methods.name: WriteStream:_write
methods.desc: Internal write utility. Bind the declared _write in your inherited class to be called when the file is opened

methods.name: WriteStream:close
methods.desc: Closes or destroys the write stream. Calls self:destroy()

methods.name: WriteStream:destroy
methods.desc: Closes the write stream

classes.name: fs.WriteStreamSync
classes.desc: A synchronous version of the WriteStream class. Extends WriteStream

classes.name: fs.ReadStream
classes.desc: A parent class for creating readable streams from files. You should extend the following class methods in your extended instance

methods.name: ReadStream:initialize
methods.desc: Initializer for the ReadStream class. Options table key values: fd - file descriptor mode path offset chunkSize length

methods.name: ReadStream:open
methods.desc: Callback to fire when the read stream is opened. This callback gets no arguments. An open event is also emitted with the file descriptor when the file is opened

methods.name: ReadStream:_read
methods.desc: Reads a file, n chunk bytes at a time. You can set the n in the init options

methods.name: ReadStream:close
methods.desc: Closes the readstream.

methods.name: ReadStream:destroy
methods.desc: Destroys the readstream. Gets called by close. Emits 'error' with err if theres an error.

modules.name: helpful
modules.desc: Levenshtein distance for property-not-found hints in modules.

methods.name: levenshtein
methods.desc: Adds a levenshtein distance function to luas native string library. The string library in luvit gets auto populated with luas string library and inbuilt methods. You can use it by simply going string.levenshtein(str1, str2). No require statements needed.

modules.name: http_codec
modules.desc:
A simple pair of functions for converting between hex and raw strings.
local httpCodec = require('http-codec')

methods.name: encoder
methods.desc: Returns a function. See the source at http.lua:ServerResponse for an example.

methods.name: decoder
methods.desc: Returns a function which takes one argument. See the source at http.lua for an example.

modules.name: http
modules.desc:
Node-style http client and server module for luvit

local http = require('http')

properties.name: headerMeta
properties.desc: Provide a nice case insensitive interface to headers. Pulled from https://github.com/creationix/weblit/blob/master/libs/weblit-app.lua

classes.name: http.IncomingMessage
classes.desc: Incoming message class, extends net.Socket.

methods.name: IncomingMessage:initialize
methods.desc:
Head is headers. Headers declared in this child class, i.e. options expected in the head table: 

- version - httpVersion
// Server specific
- method
- path - url
// Client specific
- code - statusCode
- reason - statusMessage

methods.name: IncomingMessage:_read
methods.desc: Resumes self.socket

modules.name: https
modules.desc:
Node-style https client and server module for luvit. HTTPS is the HTTP protocol over TLS/SSL.

local https = require('https')

modules.name: json
modules.desc:
local json = require('json')

Alternatively you can use lpeg like so: 

local json = require('json').use_lpeg()

methods.name: stringify
methods.desc:
Serialize a Lua table into a JSON string. 

local tbl = { username = "Groucho" }
local json_str = json.stringify( tbl )

methods.name: encode
methods.desc: Alias for json.stringify

methods.name: parse
methods.desc:
Deserialize a JSON string into a Lua table. 

local json_str = '{ "username": "Groucho" }'
local tbl = json.parse( json_str )

methods.name: decode
methods.desc: Alias for json.parse

methods.name: quotestring
methods.desc: Quotes a string. Based on the regexp "escapable" in https://github.com/douglascrockford/JSON-js

properties.name: null
properties.desc:
A null property type for JSON encoding. 

local tbl = { user = "Jane", is_working = json.null }
local json_str = json.stringify( tbl )

modules.name: light_operating_system_helper
modules.desc:
Also known as los. Its' a tiny helper to get os name in luvit.

local los = require('los')

methods.name: type
methods.desc: Returns either Windows, Linux, OSX, BSD, POSIX or Other depending on the host operating system.

modules.name: net
modules.desc:
Node-style net client and server module for luvit

local net = require('net')

methods.name: Socket:initialize
methods.desc: The Socket initializer called when an instance is generated with Socket:new(). You can pass in a number to options and the module will try to guess if a handler of type TCP or PIPE is required, or specify a handler like so: Socket:new({handle = 'Valid handle type'})

methods.name: Socket:resume
methods.desc:
Works as either 

local options = {
  host = ...,
  port = ...
}
connect(options, [cb])

or 

connect(port, [host, cb])

methods.name: Socket:connect
methods.desc:
Works as either 

local options = {
  host = ...,
  port = ...
}
connect(options, [cb])

or 

connect(port, [host, cb])

methods.name: Socket:destroy
methods.desc: Default queueSize is 128

methods.name: Socket:listen
methods.desc: Default queueSize is 128

methods.name: createConnection
methods.desc:
createConnection(port, host, callback)
or createConnection({port = ..., host = ..., callback = ...})

Creates, configures, connects and returns a new Socket instance.

methods.name: connect
methods.desc: Alias for net.createConnection(...)

methods.name: createServer
methods.desc: Creates, configures, initializes and returns a new Server instance.

modules.name: path
modules.desc:
This module contains utilities for handling and transforming file paths. Almost all these methods perform only string transformations. The file system is not consulted to check whether paths are valid. Supports both windows and posix.

Use require('path') to use this module. The following methods are provided:

methods.name: getRoot
methods.desc: Gets the filesystems root path.

methods.name: getSep
methods.desc: Gets the filesystems default path seperator

methods.name: pathEquals
methods.desc: Checks if path a is equal to b

methods.name: normalize
methods.desc:
Normalize a string path, taking care of '..' and '.' parts.

When multiple slashes are found, they're replaced by a single one; when the path contains a trailing slash, it is preserved. On Windows backslashes are used.

methods.name: join
methods.desc: Joins a splat of different strings together with the default seperator to form a valid path

methods.name: resolve
methods.desc:
Works backwards, joining the arguments until it resolves to an absolute path. If an absolute path is not resolved, then the current working directory is prepended

E.g. 

> path.resolve('/foo/bar', '/tmp/file/')
'/tmp/file/'

methods.name: relative
methods.desc: Returns the relative path from 'from' to 'to' If no relative path can be solved, then 'to' is returned

methods.name: dirname
methods.desc: Return the directory name of a path. Similar to the Unix dirname command.

methods.name: basename
methods.desc: Return the last portion of a path. Similar to the Unix basename command.

methods.name: extname
methods.desc: Return the extension of the path, from the last '.' to end of string in the last portion of the path. If there is no '.' in the last portion of the path or the first character of it is '.', then it returns an empty string. Examples:

methods.name: isAbsolute
methods.desc: Checks if filepath is absolute

methods.name: isUNC
methods.desc: Checks if the path follows Microsofts universal naming convention

methods.name: isDriveRelative
methods.desc: Drive-relative paths are unique to Windows and use the format <letter>:filepath

methods.name: normalizeSeparators
methods.desc: Returns file path with posix seperators

modules.name: pretty_print
modules.desc:
A lua value pretty printer and colorizer for terminals.

local prettyPrint = require('pretty-print')

methods.name: loadColors
methods.desc: Index lets you optionally pick a theme, 16 or 256.

methods.name: print
methods.desc: Works like the default lua print function. We also override the default lua print function

properties.name: theme
properties.desc: Table of keys and values of the available themes

modules.name: process
modules.desc:
Node-style global process table for luvit

local process = require('process')

modules.name: query_string
modules.desc: This module provides utilities for dealing with query strings. It provides the following methods:

methods.name: stringify
methods.desc:
Serialize an object to a query string. Optionally override the default separator ('&') and assignment ('=') characters.

Options object may contain encodeURIComponent property (querystring.escape by default), it can be used to encode string with non-utf8 encoding if necessary.

Example: 

querystring.stringify({ foo: 'bar', baz: ['qux', 'quux'], corge: '' })
// returns
'foo=bar&baz=qux&baz=quux&corge='

querystring.stringify({foo: 'bar', baz: 'qux'}, ';', ':')
// returns
'foo:bar;baz:qux'

// Suppose gbkEncodeURIComponent function already exists,
// it can encode string with `gbk` encoding
querystring.stringify({ w: '', foo: 'bar' }, null, null,
  { encodeURIComponent: gbkEncodeURIComponent })
// returns
'w=%D6%D0%CE%C4&foo=bar'

methods.name: parse
methods.desc:
Deserialize a query string to an object. Optionally override the default separator ('&') and assignment ('=') characters.

Options object may contain maxKeys property (equal to 1000 by default), it'll be used to limit processed keys. Set it to 0 to remove key count limitation.

Options object may contain decodeURIComponent property (querystring.unescape by default), it can be used to decode a non-utf8 encoding string if necessary.

Example: 

querystring.parse('foo=bar&baz=qux&baz=quux&corge')
// returns
{ foo: 'bar', baz: ['qux', 'quux'], corge: '' }

// Suppose gbkDecodeURIComponent function already exists,
// it can decode `gbk` encoding string
querystring.parse('w=%D6%D0%CE%C4&foo=bar', null, null,
  { decodeURIComponent: gbkDecodeURIComponent })
// returns
{ w: '', foo: 'bar' }

methods.name: urlencode
methods.desc:
Escapes special characters in a url 

querystring.urlencode('https://github.com/luvit/luvit/blob/master/deps/querystring.lua')

Returns 

'https%3A%2F%2Fgithub%2Ecom%2Fluvit%2Fluvit%2Fblob%2Fmaster%2Fdeps%2Fquerystring%2Elua'

methods.name: urldecode
methods.desc:
Un-escapes special characters in a url 

querystring.urldecode('https%3A%2F%2Fgithub%2Ecom%2Fluvit%2Fluvit%2Fblob%2Fmaster%2Fdeps%2Fquerystring%2Elua')

Returns 

'https://github.com/luvit/luvit/blob/master/deps/querystring.lua'

modules.name: readline
modules.desc:
A readline interface for terminals in pure lua.

local readline = require('readline')

modules.name: repl
modules.desc:
Implementation of a read-execute-print-loop in Luvit. Used by the Luvit repl which is returned when the Luvit binary is executed without args.
Some of the examples/samples in these docs are generated by running luvit code in this repl.
Additionally require names in the docs follow the ones automatically added into the repl during bootup (e.g. pretty-print is name-spaced as prettyPrint in the repl).
All the luvit deps are injected into the repl at runtime to make it easier to try and experiment with the luvit ecosystem.

modules.name: require
modules.desc:
Luvit's custom require system with relative requires and sane search paths.
This allows us to have the convenience of having node style require statements to include libraries.

modules.name: stream
modules.desc:
A port of node.js's stream module for luvit.

local Stream = require('Stream')

classes.name: Stream.Stream
classes.desc:
This is the stream core or base. Extends the emitter class described in Core.

You will most likely not use this class. The only relevant part of this class, the pipe method, is overriden in Readable.

classes.name: Stream.ReadableState
classes.desc: Used to hold state by the Readable class

methods.name: ReadableState:initialize
methods.desc:
Options table:

  • HighWaterMark - Defaults to 16, maxes out at 128MB. 128MB limit cannot be overwritten without modifying luvit/deps/stream/stream_readable
  • objectMode - If false/nil then the highWaterMark is set to 16 * 1024

classes.name: Stream.Readable
classes.desc: Extends Stream.Stream, implements a readable stream interface. Uses ReadableState to keep track of self._readableState

methods.name: Readable:push
methods.desc: Manually shove something into the read buffer. This returns true if the highWaterMark has not been hit yet, similar to how Writable.write() returns true if you should write() some more.

methods.name: Readable:unshift
methods.desc: Unshift should always be something directly out of read()

methods.name: Readable:read
methods.desc: Reads and returns n chunk bytes

methods.name: Readable:_read
methods.desc: Internal method executed by Readable:read. Can be overwritten in child classes.

methods.name: Readable:unpipe
methods.desc: Removes pipes to dest

methods.name: Readable:on
methods.desc:
Triggers a callback fn when an event ev is triggered. E.g. 

> local child = require('stream').Readable
> child:on('foo', function() print('bar') end)
> child:emit('foo')
'bar'
> child:on('bar', function(data) print(data) end)
> child:emit('bar', 'foo')
'foo'

methods.name: Readable:resume
methods.desc: Resumes a stream

methods.name: Readable:pause
methods.desc: Pauses a stream

properties.name: addListener
properties.desc:
Alias for Readable:on
You can use Readable:addListener for an implicit self or use Readable.addListener(self, ...)

classes.name: Stream.WriteReq
classes.desc: Used internally within the Writable class.

classes.name: Stream.WritableState
classes.desc: Used internally within the Writable class to hold state.

methods.name: WritableState:initialize
methods.desc:
Options table:

  • HighWaterMark - Defaults to 16, maxes out at 128MB. 128MB limit cannot be overwritten without modifying luvit/deps/stream/stream_readable
  • objectMode - If false/nil then the highWaterMark is set to 16 * 1024

classes.name: Stream.Writable
classes.desc:
The writable stream class
Emits end when done

methods.name: Writable:initialize
methods.desc: You can modify the writable state options here, or set them.

methods.name: Writable:write
methods.desc: Manually write a chunk

methods.name: Writable:cork
methods.desc: Kind of like pause

methods.name: Writable:uncork
methods.desc: Kind of like resume

classes.name: Stream.Duplex
classes.desc: A Duplex stream is both readable and writable and inherits the functionality and methods of the aforementioned readable and writable classes.

methods.name: Duplex:initialize
methods.desc:
These options are passed along to the initializers of the readable and writable streams this class uses.
Furthermore, we can have the following key values in the options table.

  • readable - false/true
  • writable - false/true
  • allowHalfOpen - false/true

classes.name: Stream.Transform
classes.desc:
a transform stream is a readable/writable stream where you do something with the data. Sometimes it's called a "filter", but that's not a great name for it, since that implies a thing where some bits pass through, and others are simply ignored. (That would be a valid example of a transform, of course.)

While the output is causally related to the input, it's not a necessarily symmetric or synchronous transformation. For example, a zlib stream might take multiple plain-text writes(), and then emit a single compressed chunk some time in the future.

Here's how this works:

The Transform stream has all the aspects of the readable and writable stream classes. When you write(chunk), that calls _write(chunk,cb) internally, and returns false if there's a lot of pending writes buffered up. When you call read(), that calls _read(n) until there's enough pending readable data buffered up.

In a transform stream, the written data is placed in a buffer. When _read(n) is called, it transforms the queued up data, calling the buffered _write cb's as it consumes chunks. If consuming a single written chunk would result in multiple output chunks, then the first outputted bit calls the readcb, and subsequent chunks just go into the read buffer, and will cause it to emit 'readable' if necessary.

This way, back-pressure is actually determined by the reading side, since _read has to be called to start processing a new chunk. However, a pathological inflate type of transform can cause excessive buffering here. For example, imagine a stream where every byte of input is interpreted as an integer from 0-255, and then results in that many bytes of output. Writing the 4 bytes {ff,ff,ff,ff} would result in 1kb of data being output. In this case, you could write a very small amount of input, and end up with a very large amount of output. In such a pathological inflating mechanism, there'd be no way to tell the system to stop doing the transform. A single 4MB write could cause the system to run out of memory.

However, even in such a pathological case, only a single written chunk would be consumed, and then the rest would wait (un-transformed) until the results of the previous transformed chunk were consumed.

methods.name: Transform:initialize
methods.desc: Extendable initializer for the Transform class.

methods.name: Transform:_transform
methods.desc:
The internal transform method. You must define this in your child class. E.g. implement a passthrough filter aka a very fancy way to print hello world 

local Transform = require('stream').Transform
local Transformer = Transform:extend()
function Transformer:initialize()
  Transform.initialize(self, {objectMode = true})
end

function Transformer:_transform(line, cb)
  self:push(line)
  return cb()
end

local transformer = Transformer:new()
transformer:on('data', print)
transformer:write('hello world')

classes.name: Stream.PassThrough
classes.desc:
An extension of the transform stream class with the transform method declared.
Basically just the most minimal sort of Transform stream. Every written chunk gets output as-is.

classes.name: Stream.Observable
classes.desc: Observable is a stream that can be observed outside the pipeline. observe() returns a new Readable stream that emits all data that passes through this stream. Streams created by observe() do not affect back-pressure.

modules.name: thread
modules.desc:
Thread module for luvit

local thread = require('thread')

methods.name: queue
methods.desc: Luvit threadpool

classes.name: thread.Worker
classes.desc: Luvit threadpool

modules.name: timer
modules.desc:
Javascript style setTimeout and setInterval for luvit

local timer = require('timer')

methods.name: clearInterval
methods.desc: Alias for clearInterval

methods.name: clearTimeout
methods.desc: Alias for clearInterval

methods.name: clearTimer
methods.desc: Alias for clearTimeout

modules.name: url
modules.desc: Node-style url codec for luvit

methods.name: parse
methods.desc:
Takes a url string, returns an object. Optional second argument of type bool. Pass in true if you'd like to pass the query part of the url through the querystring modules parse function. 

url = require('url')
url.parse('https://github.com/luvit/luvit/blob/master/deps/url.lua')

Returns 

{ host = 'github.com', hostname = 'github.com', href = 'https://github.com/luvit/luvit/blob/master/deps/url.lua', protocol = 'https',
  pathname = '/luvit/luvit/blob/master/deps/url.lua', path = '/luvit/luvit/blob/master/deps/url.lua' }

modules.name: utils
modules.desc:
Wrapper around pretty-print with extra tools for luvit

local utils = require('utils')

Everything in pretty-print is available under the utils namespace as well. Additionally utils has the following available functions

methods.name: noop
methods.desc: Used heavily within luvit to wrap luv methods and expose them.

methods.name: adapt
methods.desc: Used heavily within luvit to wrap luv methods and expose them.
